user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext:
```c
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext:
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
#define OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED ((osal_id_t){0})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments that use compiler-specific language extensions (such as GCC/Clang statement expressions ({ ... }), __attribute__ / __asm__ / typeof / __extension__, Microsoft __declspec, or other vendor-specific keywords) as explicitly documented as extensions. Specific notes:

- The macro OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED uses a compound literal ((osal_id_t){0}). Compound literals are part of standard C (since C99), not a vendor extension.
- The use of bool and false/true corresponds to standard C99 _Bool / stdbool.h usage, not a compiler extension.
- The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and the use of the address-of operator (&) and array indexing are all standard C constructs.
- Control flow (do/while, if, break), pointer/struct usage, increment operator (++), and return of a bool are standard C language features.

Therefore there are no fragments in the provided code that should be flagged for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions). If you expect a specific compiler where a construct here is documented as an extension, provide that compiler documentation and I will re-evaluate against those vendor-specific extension lists.
